title: typeface for business card
content:
Hi,

I’m looking for a typeface for the business card of an architect. It should be fresh & original but “professional” in the same time - I mean the feeling everything she designs meets the standards. It might have some “square” elements as her personal logo is square too.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080312041617im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/mt_bc_1_4522.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080312041617im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/mt_bc_2_5292.jpg)

Any suggestions would be very appreciated.

\_\_  
AL

 [‹ Biz Card Review](http://web.archive.org/web/20080312041617/http:/www.typophile.com/node/29754 "Go to previous forum topic") [what TYPE fashion is in at the moment? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080312041617/http:/www.typophile.com/node/29707 "Go to next forum topic")
author: aleksander

comments.content:
It actually looks quite good in Helvetica.

If you insist on changing it, you could go with something like [Heldustry](http://web.archive.org/web/20080312041617/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&font_categories_search=font_name_search&searchstr=heldustry&image.x=0&image.y=0), the love-child of Helvetica and Eurostile.

- Lex

I’d add some extra space between the capital letters of tour name. They look somewhat cluttered.

César Puertas  
diseñador (tipo)gráfico
